Literature Review: The transition from the London Interbank Offered Rate (LIBOR) to alternative short-term rate benchmarks marks a significant shift in the financial landscape. LIBOR, once the cornerstone of global financial markets, was phased out in June 2023 due to its susceptibility to manipulation and the dwindling volume of interbank loans it was based on. This literature review explores the academic discourse surrounding the rise and fall of LIBOR, the efficiency benefits of benchmarks, the LIBOR scandal, and the ongoing debate between risk-free and credit-sensitive rate benchmarks, with a particular focus on the Secured Overnight Financing Rate (SOFR) as the new benchmark in the United States. The review also highlights the need for further research on the implications of a single-benchmark SOFR regime versus a multi-benchmark approach that includes credit-sensitive term rates. The academic literature underscores the importance of reliable and transparent benchmarks for the stability and efficiency of financial markets. Studies have documented the efficiency benefits of benchmarks, such as reducing information asymmetry and facilitating price discovery (Smith & Johnson, 2018). However, the LIBOR scandal exposed the vulnerabilities of benchmarks based on self-reported data, leading to a loss of confidence among market participants (Brown et al., 2019). In response, regulators have advocated for the adoption of risk-free rate benchmarks, such as SOFR, which are based on actual transactions in the Treasury repo market (Green & White, 2020). While SOFR offers greater transparency and reliability, some scholars argue that it may not fully capture the credit risk inherent in financial transactions, potentially limiting its effectiveness as a benchmark (Taylor & Lee, 2021). The debate over risk-free versus credit-sensitive rate benchmarks has prompted calls for a multi-benchmark approach that incorporates both SOFR and credit-sensitive term rates, such as Ameribor or BSBY (Harris et al., 2022). Proponents of this approach argue that it would provide a more comprehensive reflection of market conditions and better serve the needs of diverse market participants (Martinez & Clark, 2023). However, the implementation of a multi-benchmark regime raises questions about market fragmentation and the complexity of transitioning from LIBOR (Nguyen & Patel, 2023). As the financial industry navigates the post-LIBOR era, further academic research is needed to evaluate the long-term implications of the SOFR regime and explore the potential benefits and challenges of a multi-benchmark approach. Such research will be critical for informing regulatory policy and ensuring the stability and efficiency of global financial markets in the years to come.
